metadata.name: CHAOS #2
metadata.description:
A girl from IRAN with poor internet connection addressed to the whole world: 

" we live in a world where we are promised peace and freedom and most importantly order and justice. As we humans have fallen into each other's rights. We kill each other. We lie and deceive each other. We are looking for power and all the order that we created in this world, in other living beings, in the sky, in the sea, in tiny drops of water, in the cells and atoms that make up our body. We are living in a world where freedom, justice and order have no meaning. 
We are stuck in CHAOS!"

IN MEMORY OF #MAHSA_AMINI

metadata.name: Microgravity #879
metadata.description:
Microgravity is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at The Ever-Evolving World of Art, Art Basel Hong-Kong, 2022.

Scale symmetry of abstract semiliquid forms.

Click on a section of the image to explore deeper.
- Use keys [0-9] to change the detail level.
- Use the "S" key to save a PNG image.
- Use the "R" key to reset the coordinates.

metadata.name: Natt #4
metadata.description:
Natt is a short exploration of a view. On not so recent travels I captured a photo of a small town across a large body of water. It was night and the photograph was blurry, but the emotion stayed with me. It was an emotion of calm and tranquility, accepting the darkness of night and knowing that across the water was a group of people living together, creating a beacon of light. 

Natt is the generative take on this photograph, attempting to capture the same emotion in a purely digital format. 


Press “space” to pause the animation and “s” to save the current view.

For higher resolutions, add “?pd=x” (x being a number >1) to the url when in live view and refresh, then press “s” to save. Note, for higher values of “x” rendering will take longer, start with a low number like 2-3 and work your way up to the desired size. 


Generative artwork by Tengil, 2022.

For licenses see bundle.js.LICENSE.txt.

metadata.name: Klyft #394
metadata.description:
“Klyft” is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at PARIS+ par Art Basel.

Klyft is a juxtaposition of two different projections for the future. One, made by the World Economic Forum, suggests that the global gender gap will have closed by the year 2154. The other, by the UN IPCC, estimates that global warming will reach 3.2 degrees celcius by the year 2100.

Klyft makes use of the unique temporal aspect of computational art by developing its expression gradually over the next 132 years. As we come closer to 2154, the space between the two shapes in Klyft will grow smaller to symbolize the closing of the gender gap. As time goes on, however, Klyft also becomes more and more glitched out to represent the projected increases in greenhouse gases and climate catastrophes.

In the end, Klyft’s expression will be heavily corrupted, and the two shapes will have reached each other.

· URL parameters ·

You can add the following parameters to the URL to change the behavior of the piece.

date=<YYYY-MM-DD> — See how Klyft looks on another day. Use the format YYYY-MM-DD. 

color=<number> — See the piece in another color scheme. The numbers loop around, so 17 equals 0, 18 equals 1, etc. 

resolution=<number> — View the piece in a higher resolution. 1 is normal resolution, 2 is double, etc. No decimals allowed.

image=true — Save the piece as an image. 

record=true — Save the piece as a video in WEBM format.

Adding the following URL parameters will show Klyft in double resolution on the day gender equality is achieved according to the WEF:

date=2154-01-01&resolution=2

Adding the following URL parameters will save a video of Klyft in the ‘Stokkendahl Dalgas’ color scheme:

color=14&record=true

· Interactions ·

Pressing the following keys will trigger functionality as well as add related URL parameters automatically. 

Pressing D will increment the date by 1 year.

Pressing C will increment the color index by 1.

Pressing R will toggle between normal and double resolution.

Pressing I will toggle the image URL parameter, which saves the piece as an image. Only works outside of iframe.

Pressing V will toggle the video URL parameter, which saves the piece as a video. Only works outside of iframe.

There are secret key presses as well. Some of them only work outside of iframe. 

· Accessibility ·

Klyft is built to support screen readers. It has been tested using MacOS’ VoiceOver, and uses p5.js’ describeElement() to provide screen reader functionality.

If you have any comments (good or bad) on the screen reader integration, don’t hesitate to reach out on my Twitter: @ada_ada_ada_art. 

· Credits and license ·

Klyft is made with p5.js.

Klyft is licensed under a modified version of the Climate Strike License (CSL).

metadata.name: Miniscapes #122
metadata.description:
Miniscapes merges generative code (Rich's bit) with meticulously designed scenes and elements (Rick's bit), to create minimalist landscapes intended to charm, delight, and surprise.

Our aim was to convey as much as possible with as little as possible by using simple shapes and lines to represent a wide variety of natural landscapes.

We hope that you find as much joy in owning a Miniscape as we did in creating them.

Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to save the current image
- Press [p] to pause an animated output
- Press [r] to reset an animated output (this will also pause)

metadata.name: Sedimentary Dissolution #370
metadata.description:
This piece is inspired by the geological processes related to sedimentary dissolution. Dissolution is a form of weathering which contributes to the creation of new rocks. In this piece, various algorithms take on the role of dissolution, producing visual recombinations of the original "sedimentary rock".

Instructions ::

p : save a hi-res image
e : toggle erosion on and off
s : toggle structure on and off
a : toggle all effects on and off

If offset, rgb dissolution or cross-bedding is true you can toggle it on and off.
If these features are false pressing the key will have no effect.

o : toggle offset on and off
r : toggle rgb dissolution on and off
c : toggle cross-bedding on and off

There are 20 versions you can explore, all using the same features.
Use the left and right arrow to change the random seed. 
Pressing space will re-instantiate the original random seed.

metadata.name: BUD #11
metadata.description:
Whatever you hit me with the ax didn't hurt me, it turned into a bud.

For years we were suppressed, ignored, wounded, fell to our knees, died and came back to life.

In memory of Mahsa_Amini

metadata.name: BUD #13
metadata.description:
Whatever you hit me with the ax didn't hurt me, it turned into a bud.

For years we were suppressed, ignored, wounded, fell to our knees, died and came back to life.

metadata.name: Dots #49
metadata.description:
Press p to save a hi-res image.

Press any other key to toggle between two views. Please note that this change will not happen instantaneously, as it will take a number of seconds for the code to run.

metadata.name: Heat Death #786
metadata.description:
Heat Death is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at The Ever-Evolving World of Art, Art Basel Hong-Kong, 2022

It aims to produce variation and detail from minimal logic.

The source code uses p5.js and consists of around 180 lines of code. It has been left unminified for the interested viewer to learn more.

metadata.name: Absorbed #9
metadata.description:
A collaboration between leading British high-end audio brand KEF, generative artist hieroglyphica, and creative studio Parameta, Absorbed embodies the process of noise becoming high-fidelity sound through KEF’s Metamaterial Absorption Technology (MAT™). 

MAT™ makes the KEF sound what it is: absorbing unwanted distortion to deliver pure, accurate sound exactly as the artist intended. Inspired by this intricacy, Absorbed illustrates pseudorandom networks of patterns, slowly emerging and transforming into the maze-like form of MAT™. Clarity is revealed, noise is absorbed – high-fidelity is found.

The noise fields used in Absorbed are of two distinct types: conventional gradient noise and “sinusoidal” noise, an original algorithm developed for this series. The use of animation as artistic medium reflects the artists’ belief that no single frame can capture the full range of complexity found in the tension between sound and noise, and lets collectors observe for themselves this ever-shifting dialogue. A more extensive discussion of the algorithms used in Absorbed can be found in hieroglyphica’s companion article on fx(text).

- spacebar will pause and resume the animation
- s will save a still image of the current frame
- technically minded collectors can consult the index.html file for info on how to render and save high-resolution images
- use of hardware acceleration in Chrome may impact performance

Founded by BBC engineer Raymond Cooke in 1961, KEF is a leading British innovator of high-end audio products including HiFi speakers, subwoofers, architectural speakers, wireless speaker-systems, and headphones. Find out more at kef.com or visit our Discord at discord.com/invite/u48Z9yjY2q.

metadata.name: SMOLSKULL #591
metadata.description:
Smol pixelart skull face

Generative art by Mark Knol (@mknol)

metadata.name: Coronado #9
metadata.description:
This series is about the beauty and charm of imperfection, chaos amidst order, and letting go. It's about knowing that however much control we think we may have, things can all fall apart or burst into something unexpectedly wonderful at any moment, even without our hands tightly on the reigns.

Please see fxtext article linked from main project page for more background on the project and rendering notes.

Some key commands in live mode:

G : Toggle grain
S : Save current resolution
1 : 4000x5000
2 : 6000x7500
3 : 8000x10000
4 : 10000x12500
5 : 12000x15000
6 : 14000x17500
(1-6 work best on Chrome)
(rendering takes longer as resolution increases)

metadata.name: Metropolis IX #9
metadata.description:
We divide spaces into smaller spaces which we conquer and live in our solitude. We call that Metropolis.

Started this piece as a rule based generative art. Simply the algorithm takes a rectangle and throws 2 random points inside it within defined x and y distances. Then using those 2 points, algorithm draws another rectangle and assigns letters to the corners of rectangle "A,B,C,D" starting from top left corner in clockwise direction. Then it starts to draw cells from inner rectangle's corner A to parent's corner A and goes on. Once 4 cells are created, it creates 4 more cells in between other cells, thus dividing a rectangle into 9 pieces. This is where "IX" comes from. Depending on the cell properties; algorithm assigns circles, triangles, lines and points to cells creating a city scape when certain parameters are given to the division algorithm.

There are 18 possible outcomes:
"Hazy Day" 13% probability (half of this style will come with slightly more color transition)
"Hazy Night" 10% probability
"Crystal Day" 11% probability
"Crystal Night" 5% probability
"Mondrian Day"  3% probability
"Mondrian Night" 3% probability
"Bauhaus Day" 3% probability
"Bauhaus Night" 3% probability
"1 Chroma Day" 4% probability (Multiple values of a single hue on a monochrome gradient)
"Mondrian Crystal Day" 3% probability
"Mondrian Crystal Night" 3% probability
"Monochrome Day" 3% probability 
"Monochrome Night" 4% probability 
"Vibrant Day" 12% probability
"Vibrant Night" 9% probability
"Rainbow Day' 5% probability
"Rainbow Night' 3% probability
"Chaotic Day"   3% probability (which takes pretty random parameters and 25% of this outcome has probability of creating very first coloring style of the project, see console for the hidden feature)




Press "1" to download 1000px height PNG
Press "2" to download 2000px height PNG
Press "3" to download 3000px height PNG
Press "4" to download 4000px height PNG
Press "5" to download 5000px height PNG
Press "6" to download 6000px height PNG
Press "7" to download 7000px height PNG
Press "8" to download 8000px height PNG
Press "9" to download 12000px height PNG
Press "m' to download 900x1600px PNG for mobile wallpaper

Use CTRL+SHIFT+C or CMD+SHIFT+C to open console for hidden features

Created from scratch with p5.js 
Murat Atimtay 2022 | @atimtay | www.muratatimtay.com

metadata.name: Fire Card #199
metadata.description:
Fire Cards is a series of generative artworks inspired by 19th-century Japanese fireworks catalogues. The images in these catalogues didn't so much focus on realism, but on the visual associations of the pyrotechnic effects instead. Using a restricted color palette and relatively simple shapes, this resulted in vibrant, graphical posters that sparked your own imagination more than anything else.

In Fire Cards, the abstract, static images are transformed back into lively, dynamic worlds again, each with their own distinctive, centuries-old aesthetics. Using a custom animation and 2D render system, the algorithmically generated worlds slowly build up and show a magical fireworks performance.

Fire Cards are tiny, personal and unique shows of wonder.
